ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to become a more concise and precise writer. I also learned how to more quickly read and annotate the materials for class discussion.
This course allowed me to develop a better analytical perspective through a variety of interesting readings and also built up my argumentative writing skills.

The course was a general discussion about the topic of voice, what it is, why it's important, it's relation to body and what constitutes a voice. I came to better understand voices around me, their importance, and to appreciate certain voices that I've completely neglected beforehand.
Writing skills, precision with my writing, practice writing essays and papers effectively.

Through this course, I was able to improve my writing and learn how to substantiate my arguments. I also learned a lot about voices, how we perceive them, and the roles they play in our lives. I also feel that this course helped me understand my own voice better and how I use it, especially through writing, to communicate the ideas that I am interested in.
voices
I developed my writing skills and learned how to better structure essays. In addition to that, I also learned how to effectively take notes, and to focus on bigger themes rather than details.
I learned about the concept of voice and how it is composed both of the listener and the perceiver. Also, I learned a lot about the voice-body connection.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: professorProfessor Tu is an amazing resource, and she is always willing to help you and review any of your writing; curriculumfour essays is a manageable workload, and the readings never felt overwhelming

Weaknesses: quality of readingsI sometimes felt that the readings were disorganized and scattered, and I was left wondering why we had even read the piece; in-class writing lessonsthe exercises and mini-lessons we had on writing seemed forced and, at times, repetitive and pedantic.

This course provided really interesting material to work through. While it was occasionally difficult to focus on writing in the morning, Prof Tu showcased a wide variety of media in class that enabled critical thinking in a very approachable way.

The topics of discussion were really engaging! The research paper, yet challenging, was extremely rewarding.
Some readings could be dropped for lack of relevance.
Strengths include great feedback and engagement throughout the course. No weaknesses.
very nice and clear

Strengths: The professor is flexible with office hours and very eager to individually help each student. The readings are varied and not overwhelming.
Weaknesses: Some readings are difficult to follow. They're only understood once discussed in class. We didn't tend to have peer-peer discussions, instead it's usually between a student and the professor.

Strengths: Professor Tu genuinely cares about her students. The feedback on each paper definitely helped a lot and I appreciated her willingness to assist during office hours a LOT. This was the perfect first semester course to develop my writing skills, and her insights into the seminar helped us move the conversation forward. She incorporated a lot of media into the lectures which changed up any monotony. Also, Professor Tu is very understanding. She prioritizes mental and physical health before academic success, and that makes for a very comfortable and growth-minded learning environment.

Weaknesses: Sometimes, the seminar conversations were not fluid and it felt as though we were responding more to Professor Tu than to each other by raising our hands and such. Perhaps some seminar conversation guidelines and some direct conversation could make the conversation feel more natural.

Maybe, with the readings, adding more content that allows for debate or more-passionate discussion could actually facilitate more conversation too. I liked the readings, but maybe charging some content could facilitate more early-morning engagement. Maybe comparing different voices and opinions, how people voice those opinions, etcetera, could add some more nuance to the course. Finally, playing some music in the beginning of class could make the environment feel a bit more natural and even contribute to perceiving voice!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
I would recommend ENGL 114it is a good introduction to the writing courses available at Yale. I was a little worried about what Yale would require from academic writing, but this course gave me confidence that I was ready to write at the college-level. 

However, I would not recommend this particular course (Voices, Silence, and Self). The subject was a little disorganized, and this disconnect reflected in some of the readings we had.

Yes, this course gives you a lot of creative freedom and allows you to develop as a writer. While some of the topics might seem really open-ended at first, Prof Tu provides a lot of insight and individual help to develop well-written papers.
Yes. It is a great introductory course to English at Yale.
Yes, I would highly recommend this course to another student.
absolutely

I would recommend taking an ENGL 114 course. I felt like my writing and reading comprehension improved noticeably. That being said, this topic isn't for everyone, so I'd recommend looking through Coursetable.

I would recommend this course to another studentI would take this class, or any class, with Professor Tu. She provides insightful and helpful feedback, making this the perfect course to improve your writing skills. She is also understanding, lenient, and really meets a student where they are at. Also, the last assignment of the course is a creative assignment, and Professor Tu encouraged use of many types of media. I found that to be fulfilling as the instructor embraced many different people's talents and creative instincts. Professor Tu was very insightful, helpful, and listened to my stress and concerns relating to papers. I felt as though I could describe how I really felt with the progress of my paper, and she would meet me wherever I needed assistance. I did not have to go to her with a finished product, but rather we could work on the process together. She prioritizes mental and physical wellness before academic grades, and that is, to me, a sure-fire reason to take a course and learn from an instructor.
